reviews.text: Won't have you holding your breath. It has a villain unique enough to separate it from others of its ilk. BTW, the less you know about it before buying a ticket, the better.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: Ceaseless in its nail-biting tension and only becoming more breathlessly savage as it goes, "Don't Breathe" shreds one's nerves and leaves them for dead. It's easily one of the smartest, most riveting thrillers of the year.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: 'Don't Breathe' might be the creepiest movie of the year, and that's saying something after the very good "Green Room" and "The Conjuring 2" both spooked us out earlier.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: Hits all the marks of a classic. Count on a steady dose of nervous laughter and a sense of dread. And remember the title is a warning for the characters, not the audience.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: magine if somebody tried to rob blind Zatoichi and he was in a REALLY bad mood and that's the awesomeness you're in store for.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Terrific and unsettling horror-thriller. Alvarez is using film to explore his fetishes and he's doing a great job.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: Don't Breathe does a solid job of dispensing with dialogue in favor of driving the plot via strong, claustrophobic images as the camera snakes in and out of underlit rooms.
reviews.author: Joe Gross

reviews.text: Our heroes are compelled to spend so much time skulking around the house quietly that whenever one of them do make a noise, often stupidly, the entire audience groans in unison, as if they're blurting out, "Hey, blind man, I'm over here!"
reviews.author: Calum Marsh

reviews.text: Robbery crews are strongly advised to avoid 1837 Buena Vista, but moviegoers hoping for a thrill might like to visit. But don't linger.
reviews.author: Mark Kennedy

reviews.text: Alvarez knows the size of his ambitions. He's written one great ghoul, surrounded him with targets, and simply let him let rip.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: Fede Alvarez and Rodo Sayagues keep the plot twists coming, though as they accumulate the story begins to feel like a confection, succeeding not through any fresh idea but through the stubborn recombination of a few stale ones.
reviews.author: J. R. Jones

reviews.text: Don't Breathe is still a thrilling experience that effectively puts the audience in the protagonists' place: uncertain, cringing, afraid to even breathe because of the potential consequences.
reviews.author: Tasha Robinson

reviews.text: Don't Breathe is almost a throwback to older horror films. It's meticulously planned and thrillingly satisfying with a camera always a step ahead.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: It will probably please fans of this simple genre with its solid suspense, murky lighting and "gotcha!" scares.
reviews.author: Anita Gates

reviews.text: One of the most suspenseful, terrifying, and devilishly original horror pics in recent memory.
reviews.author: Tirdad Derakhshani

reviews.text: Alvarez knows how to build tension, but unfortunately he leans on narrative laziness to accomplish it, threats appearing with no explanation of how they've worked themselves out of their last predicament.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: This is a tight, tense horror with very little gore on show, relying on suspense to keep the audience on tenterhooks. Expect to see a lot more from Alvarez in future.
reviews.author: Abigail Chandler

reviews.text: This is some weird, twisted s--t. Don't groan when I say Don't Breathe is a home-invasion thriller. Director Fede Alvarez is as good as it gets when it comes to playing with things that go bump in the night.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: Great horror films are feats of direction: Scoff all you like about teenagers getting thrashed by a blind war vet, but it's Alvarez who gets the last laugh.
reviews.author: Scott Tobias

reviews.text: [Stephen Lang] delivers a Pantheon boogeyman here, conveying with every thought and gesture that this is absolutely not a man with whom to screw. This movie should be played loud.
reviews.author: Andrew Wright

reviews.text: If you're looking for straight-up blood, guts and gore horror, you'll probably be disappointed. But if you're just in the mood for a shockingly good time, don't miss "Don't Breathe.
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: It's a sharp and savvy thriller for an age in which more than half of Americans seem to feel less secure than ever -- a fear that politicians tend to stoke despite violent crime and violence being down significantly since the '90s.
reviews.author: Stephen Rebello

reviews.text: [A]n elaborately staged, finely choreographed game of cat and mouse...
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: [Though] Alvarez proves an adept stager and arranger of calculated shock effects...the script isn't concerned with even an iota of logic, but merely with generating one more empty jolt.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: "Don't Breathe" is simple, but blessedly so, focusing on the procurement of horror and suspense, wasting little of the picture on nonsense.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Satisfying, meat-and-potatoes horror that takes a simple premise, adds a couple of flourishes, makes the most of it for 85 minutes, then gets out before it can overstay its welcome.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: The home invasion thriller Don't Breathe might just be the first movie of the year that'll make you want to do exactly what the title says.
reviews.author: Mark Daniell

reviews.text: Apart from its thin characters and occasional trite moments, as well as a silly attempt to set up a sequel, "Don't Breathe" is just about perfect.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: How refreshing to see fight scenes that pivot on panicked opportunism rather than martial arts skills or mutant powers.
reviews.author: Jon Niccum

reviews.text: So inventive for its first hour, Don't Breathe strains credulity the longer this goes on. By the time the credits roll, you might find yourself breathing a sigh of relief for all the wrong reasons.
reviews.author: Michael Nordine

reviews.text: There's nothing wrong with crafting a thrill ride, but Alvarez' 'Don't Breathe' eventually goes off the rails as it veers from the exhilarating to the revolting.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: Alvarez quiets his movie down to a game of cat and mouse, a luxury in a climate in which horror is all about maximum volume.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: In what is shaping up to a banner year for scary movies, this is another solid and memorable entry.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Alvarez serves up some jaw-droppingly tasteless third-act twists to ensure this all sticks. And that's his big mistake.
reviews.author: Tom Russo

reviews.text: A devious and demonstrative piece of home-invasion mischief that also leans heavily, and ingeniously, on blindness as a crucial plot device.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: This is a movie where every jump scare is worthy of a shriek.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: Intriguingly, Don't Breathe plays with the kind of moral relativism that escapes most studio pictures.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: From the opening shot, the R-rated Don't Breathe drops us into an ominous environment crackling with suspense, jolts and uncertainty about what will happen next.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: More methodical than innovative, Don't Breathe is nevertheless an effective suspenser.
reviews.author: Marjorie Baumgarten

reviews.text: Taps into our deepest, darkest fears, and offers us a bloody, instant horror classic that's not for the faint of heart.
reviews.author: Conner Schwerdtfeger

reviews.text: Alvarez, who directed the 2010 remake of Sam Raimi's "The Evil Dead," effectively sets up a brutal cat-and-mouse game; the problem is that sometimes you don't know who to root for.
reviews.author: Pat Padua

reviews.text: It's a very effective '90s throwback thriller, where a broken man is robbed by a group of morally bankrupt kids. Have fun deciding which side are heroes and which side are villains.
reviews.author: David Medsker

reviews.text: The kind of morality play that toys with audience loyalty and conveys its protagonists' predicament by making us feel claustrophobic right alongside them.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: A clever if increasingly mechanical suspense contraption, yanking our sympathies this way and that, before turning into a different sort of movie entirely.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Three young burglars who think a blind man is easy pickings are in for a surprise in this tense, expertly crafted thriller.
reviews.author: Maitland McDonagh

reviews.text: A nice little mix tape of a horror movie, incorporating elements of familiar films into something satisfyingly different.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Alvarez appears to have consciously toned down the gore from his blood-saturated Evil Dead remake, trusting unnerving visuals and foreshadowing what terrors are about to unfold.
reviews.author: Christian Holub

reviews.text: Lang, snorting and enormous and bestial, seems like the Minotaur stalking intruders in his deadly labyrinth. For the first hour, the psychological cruelty far outweighs the physical.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: It leaves the audience in the same place as the characters: gasping for air.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: What started as an intense, gripping thriller becomes a ridiculous cartoon.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: While its script could have been written on the back of an envelope, its editing and use of sound design is a triumph.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: "One of the most twisted movies you'll see this year."
reviews.author: Jim Vejvoda

reviews.text: Connoisseurs of creepy and sometimes brutal chills will have a good time.
reviews.author: Walter V. Addiego

reviews.text: Don't Breathe makes for a very fun little thriller, though it also veers into being exceptionally stupid or eye-rollingly gross.
reviews.author: Dan Schindel

reviews.text: Once Don't Breathe detonates its big twist...some audience members will feel the film stops being fun while others will feel the fun has started in earnest.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: The script, by Alvarez and Rodo Sayagues, steadily and inventively heightens the tension of the break-in and the inevitable hiding and chasing, at least until everything gets ridiculous toward the end.
reviews.author: Alan Scherstuhl

reviews.text: While the sight-based conceit offers the opportunity for clever suspense and scares, it's the starkly realistic setting and all too newsworthy themes underpinning the spooky tale that makes the horror of this film so bone-chilling.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: Director Fede Alvarez is a pro at creating tension with nothing more than sound effects and shots that constantly have us thinking of what's outside the frame.
reviews.author: Matt Prigge

reviews.text: Don't Breathe's sustainment of its corkscrew tension is so elegant and methodical as to feel dance-like.
reviews.author: Ed Gonzalez

reviews.text: While it is definitely time for Alvarez to stretch beyond his brand of housebound horror, he just may be the current master of it.
reviews.author: Michael Fairbanks

reviews.text: An intense, streamlined exercise in gruesome thrills, with a tiny glimmer of social context (it's all about the economy) which doesn't take away from the exciting struggle to get out of this house of horrors.
reviews.author: Kim Newman

reviews.text: The type of edge-of-your seat thrills promised by its commercials, but also takes you into far darker territory than anticipated.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: DON'T BREATHE works on a primal level with a few shocking surprises along the way.
reviews.author: JimmyO

reviews.text: The blind man's house becomes a Rube Goldberg machine of suffering, for just about everybody, and it's a twisted delight to watch that chain of events unfold.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: The ending leaves room for a sequel, but it's not just a half-baked teaser. As with all strong horror stories, the conclusion of one dangerous scenario feeds the fear of more to come.
reviews.author: Eric Kohn

reviews.text: Don't Breathe is a punch to the face, delivering everything you deem tense and thrilling. It's an adrenaline shot of genre-bending ferocity.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: Don't Breathe indeed reaches a unique destination in horror filmmaking. Unfortunately it fails to deliver a worthy emotional hook to pin its savagery onto.
reviews.author: Charlie Schmidlin

reviews.text: A trapped-in-a-house thriller pitting thieves against an unexpectedly resourceful victim, the lean and mean pic offers scares aplenty and at least a couple of game-changing twists.
reviews.author: John DeFore

reviews.text: It's nice to see [Alvarez] flex his filmmaking muscles a bit more independently, and I do hope this is only the start of his very promising career as a genre director because Don't Breathe is an amazing sophomore effort.
reviews.author: Heather Wixson

reviews.text: Alvarez's Evil Dead left many wondering what this visually talented director would do next. Inconsistent and offensive, Don't Breathe is not the follow-up many will have wanted.
reviews.author: Marten Carlson

reviews.text: Don't Breathe is a masterful combination of suspense and violence that'll have you squirming in your seat and enjoying every minute of it.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: A muscular exercise in brutal, relentless peril.
reviews.author: Dennis Harvey

reviews.text: The first two-thirds are as solid a piece of thriller filmmaking as Hollywood has produced in a while.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

synopsis: Rocky (Jane Levy), Alex and Money are three Detroit thieves who get their kicks by breaking into the houses of wealthy people. Money gets word about a blind veteran who won a major cash settlement following the death of his only child. Figuring he's an easy target, the trio invades the man's secluded home in an abandoned neighborhood. Finding themselves trapped inside, the young intruders must fight for their lives after making a shocking discovery about their supposedly helpless victim.
